p.s: itIt is so great to hear from you after such a long time!
It has definetlydefinitely been a while.
In your previous e-mail you told me that you have been talking about Shakespeare in your English class.
How funny is that!
We do the same at the moment in Germany.
I know that writing an essay can be tough on this topic, so let me help you find some more information on whether Shakespeare is played in German theatres.
I guess it is your lucky day because I just found an interesting article explaining why producers in Brandenburg still put on Shakespeare's plays.

The article with the title Darum spielen wir Shakespeare published in the German newspaper MÃ¤rkische Allgemeine on the 23rd of April in 2016 written by Karim Saab presents the points of views of four producers elaborating on Shakespeare's still of relevance for the German theatre.
The first producer mentioned is Mario Holetzeck the directore of the theatre in Cottbus.
According to Holetzeck he still puts on his plays because of his uniqueness.

He believes that a wonderful thing aobut his plays are that they can be viewed and interpreted from different perspectives and helpshelp us reflect on ourselves with the help of the themes he touches on.

There is also Tobias Wellemeyer from the Hans-Otto-Theatres in Potsdam who argues that Shakespeare has had an impact on other playwrights whic has been essential for the writing of famous plays coming after him.
Next, he succeeds at connecting to his audience when portraying the individual struggles of his audiences.
Wellemeyer maintains the view that no one like Shakespeare was able to show humanity and its flaws so well.
Mr. R. Simon holds the view that not only the themes are impacting the audiences around the world but also their variety as well as their literary, poetic and rethoricalrhetorical power.
He argues that despite the whole complexity of his plays, Shakespeare's works lead to passionate discussion about humanity's most deceisivedecisive, vulnerable and crucial desires.
Lastly, there is Igor Holland from Senftenberg who gives many examples for why Shakespeare is still of relevance in German theatres.
First, the great number of his plays and their overall success is a reason as well as the timeless description of humanity.
Did you know that his works have been translated more than a hundred times?
It is also argued that the dynamics of his plays allow them to be adopted and re-interpreted all over again - in every century.
I really hope that this article will help you with your essay on Shakespeare's global appeal.
